concept_group.definition: [402002] S2.SBM-3 Material impacts, risks and opportunities and their interaction with strategy and business model

parsed_references.text: When fulfilling the requirements of paragraph 48, the undertaking shall disclose whether all consumers and/or end-users who are likely to be materially impacted by the undertaking, including impacts connected with the undertaking’s own operations and value chain, including through its products or services, as well as through its business relationships, are included in the scope of its disclosure under ESRS 2. In addition, the undertaking shall disclose the following information: (a) a brief description of the types of consumers and/or end-users subject to material impacts by its own operations or through its value chain, and specify whether they are: i. consumers and/or end-users of products that are inherently harmful to people and/or increase risks for chronic disease; ii. consumers and/or end-users of services that potentially negatively impact their rights to privacy, to have their personal data protected, to freedom of expression and to non-discrimination; iii. consumers and/or end-users who are dependent on accurate and accessible product- or service-related information, such as manuals and product labels, to avoid potentially damaging use of a product or service; iv. consumers and/or end-users who are particularly vulnerable to health or privacy impacts or impacts from marketing and sales strategies, such as children or financially vulnerable individuals; (b) in the case of material negative impacts, whether they are either (i) widespread or systemic in contexts where the undertaking sells or provides its products or services (for example, state surveillance that affects the privacy of service users), or (ii) related to individual incidents (for example, a defect linked to a particular product) or to specific business relationships (for example, a business partner uses marketing that inappropriately targets young consumers); (c) in the case of material positive impacts, a brief description of the activities that result in the positive impacts (for example, product design that improves its accessibility for persons with disabilities) and the types of consumers and/or end-users that are positively affected or could be positively affected; the undertaking may also disclose whether the positive impacts occur in specific countries or regions; and (d) any material risks and opportunities for the business arising from impacts and dependencies on consumers and/or end-users.

concept_group.definition: [404020] S4-2 Processes for engaging with consumers and end-users about impacts

parsed_references.text: The undertaking shall disclose whether and how the perspectives of consumers and/or end-users inform its decisions or activities aimed at managing actual and potential impacts on consumers and/or end-users. This shall include, where relevant, an explanation of: (a) whether engagement occurs with affected consumers and/or end-users or their legitimate representatives directly, or with credible proxies that have insight into their situation; (b) the stage(s) at which engagement occurs, the type of engagement, and the frequency of the engagement; (c) the function and the most senior role within the undertaking that has operational responsibility for ensuring this engagement happens and that the results inform the undertaking’s approach; and (d) where applicable, how the undertaking assesses the effectiveness of its engagement with consumers and/or end-users, and, where relevant, any agreements or outcomes that result from such engagement.

concept_group.definition: [401030] S1-3 Processes to remediate negative impacts and channels for own workforce to raise concerns

parsed_references.text: The undertaking shall describe: (a) its general approach to and processes for providing or contributing to remedy where it has identified that it has caused or contributed to a material negative impact on consumers and/or end-users, including whether and how the undertaking assesses that the remedy provided is effective; (b) any specific channels it has in place for consumers and/or end-users to raise their concerns or needs directly with the undertaking and have them addressed, including whether these are established by the undertaking itself and/or through participation in third-party mechanisms; (c) the processes through which the undertaking supports or requires the availability of such channels by its business relationships; and (d) how it tracks and monitors issues raised and addressed, and how it ensures the effectiveness of the channels, including through involvement of stakeholders who are the intended users.

concept_group.definition: [201310] ESRS2.MDR-A.1 Minimum Disclosure Requirement - Actions MDR-A - general
[401050] S1-5 Targets related to managing material negative impacts, advancing positive impacts, and managing material risks and opportunities

parsed_references.text: The undertaking shall disclose the time-bound and outcome-oriented targets it may have set related to: (a) reducing negative impacts on consumers and/or end-users; and/or (b) advancing positive impacts on consumers and/or end-users; and/or (c) managing material risks and opportunities related to consumers and/or end-users.

39. The undertaking shall disclose the time-bound and outcome-oriented targets it may have set related to:
(a) reducing negative impacts on value chain workers; and/or
(b) advancing positive impacts on value chain workers; and/or
(c) managing material risks and opportunities related to value chain workers.

The undertaking shall disclose the time-bound and outcome-oriented targets it may have set related to: (a) reducing negative impacts on affected communities; and/or (b) advancing positive impacts on affected communities; and/or (c) managing material risks and opportunities related to affected communities

44. The undertaking shall disclose the time-bound and outcome-oriented targets it may have set related to:
(a) reducing negative impacts on its own workforce; and/or
(b) advancing positive impacts on its own workforce; and/or
(c) managing material risks and opportunities related to its own workforce.

fact-1.value: Name of impact, risk and opportunity is Climate Transition. Our company is proactively managing its exposure to climate-related risks and leveraging opportunities to accelerate our energy transition. We have conducted a comprehensive materiality assessment that identifies regulatory changes, physical climate risks, and market shifts as key challenges, while innovations in renewable energy and digitalization offer significant growth potential. These findings have been integrated into our strategic planning and risk management frameworks to ensure that sustainability considerations are embedded across our business model.

concept_group.definition: [200730] ESRS2.SBM-3 Material impacts, risks and opportunities and their interaction with strategy and business model - general

parsed_references.text:
Disclosure Requirement SBM-3 - Material impacts, risks and opportunities and their interaction with strategy and business model
46. The undertaking shall disclose its material impacts, risks and opportunities and how they interact with its strategy and business model.

fact-3.value: Impact1: Our materiality assessment has revealed that climate-related risks and opportunities are predominantly concentrated within our energy-intensive operations and across our supply chain. Key impacts include regulatory compliance challenges, physical risks from extreme weather, and significant opportunities in renewable energy and resource efficiency. These findings have prompted strategic adjustments—such as enhanced investment in sustainable technologies, process optimization, and proactive stakeholder engagement—to bolster our resilience and drive long-term value creation. The assessment also highlights the need to continuously monitor these impacts, ensuring that our business model adapts effectively to evolving environmental and market conditions.

concept_group.definition: [200730] ESRS2.SBM-3 Material impacts, risks and opportunities and their interaction with strategy and business model - general

parsed_references.text:
Disclosure Requirement SBM 3 – Material impacts, risks and opportunities and their interaction with strategy and business model
16. The undertaking shall disclose:
(a) a list of material sites in its own operations, including sites under its operational control, based on the results of paragraph 17(a). The undertaking shall disclose these locations by:
i. specifying the activities negatively affecting biodiversity sensitive areas (73);
ii. providing a breakdown of sites according to the impacts and dependencies identified, and to the ecological status of the areas (with reference to the specific ecosystem baseline level) where they are located; and
iii. specifying the biodiversity-sensitive areas impacted, for users to be able to determine the location and the responsible competent authority with regards to the activities specified in paragraph 16(a) i.
(b) whether it has identified material negative impacts with regards to land degradation, desertification or soil sealing (74); and
(c) whether it has operations that affect threatened species (75).

fact-5.value: Impact2: Sustainable Stakeholder Engagement. Our strategic approach embeds sustainability into all aspects of our operations—ensuring that our workforce, value chain workers, local communities, and consumers benefit from our initiatives. We prioritize employee well-being and ethical labor practices, actively support community development, and emphasize product safety and transparency to build lasting trust. This integrated strategy not only fosters resilience across our value chain but also drives long-term competitive advantage.

fact-7.value: Impact3: Integrating Stakeholder Impact Insights for Strategic Adaptation. Our continuous sustainability assessments reveal that both actual and potential impacts on our workforce, value chain workers, affected communities, and consumers play a pivotal role in shaping our business strategy. Feedback from employee engagement, supplier collaboration, and community outreach initiatives has led us to refine training programs, optimize operational processes, and enhance product safety and transparency. These insights inform our decision-making processes, ensuring that our strategy and business model are continually adapted to mitigate risks and seize emerging opportunities.

fact-9.value: Impact4: Our materiality assessment has identified a diverse range of stakeholders who are subject to material impacts. In our own workforce, this includes full-time employees, self-employed individuals, and workers provided by third-party organizations, all of whom are monitored for both potential risks—such as exposure to unsafe conditions—and opportunities for upskilling and career development. Similarly, in our value chain, workers in extraction, manufacturing, logistics, and distribution are evaluated for adverse impacts, including those related to forced or child labor, as well as for positive outcomes like improved working conditions through capacity-building initiatives. Furthermore, affected communities—whether those living near our operational sites or those connected to our supply network—are assessed for socio-economic and environmental impacts, while consumers and end-users are considered in terms of product safety, information accessibility, and overall impact on quality of life. This comprehensive mapping informs our strategy to mitigate risks and enhance positive impacts throughout our entire value chain.

fact-12.value: Impact5: Enhanced Understanding of Consumer Vulnerability. Through our comprehensive materiality assessment, we have identified that certain groups of consumers and end‐users—such as the elderly, children, and individuals with preexisting conditions—may be at a greater risk of harm from specific products or services. In response, we have developed targeted measures including improved product safety standards, clear and accessible labeling, and dedicated consumer education initiatives. These actions are integrated into our overall strategy to ensure that our offerings are both safe and beneficial, thereby mitigating risks and enhancing positive outcomes.

fact-14.value: Impact7: Positive Impact Initiatives. Our operations implement targeted activities that generate positive outcomes for our workforce, value chain workers, affected communities, and consumers. Key initiatives include comprehensive training programs, health and safety enhancements, and community development projects that drive job creation and upskilling. These actions not only improve working conditions but also foster innovation and long-term resilience across our value chain, thereby contributing to sustainable growth and stakeholder well-being.

fact-15.value: Impact11: Region-Specific Positive Outcomes. Our targeted sustainability initiatives have yielded significant positive impacts in specific regions, particularly in emerging markets. Localized capacity-building programs, enhanced labor standards, and community development projects have contributed to increased employment opportunities and improved working conditions. By tailoring our efforts to the unique needs of these regions, we are able to drive socio-economic upliftment and ensure that our sustainability strategy creates lasting value where it is needed most.

fact-16.value: We identified a potential risk regarding data misuse in our supply chain, which can negatively affect user privacy and trust (impact materiality) as well as expose us to regulatory fines, legal costs, and lost revenue (financial materiality). We also see an opportunity to differentiate our products through stronger data protections, building user trust and reducing potential financial liabilities.

concept_group.definition: [200730] ESRS2.SBM-3 Material impacts, risks and opportunities and their interaction with strategy and business model - general

parsed_references.text: When fulfilling the requirements of paragraph 48, the undertaking shall disclose whether all consumers and/or end-users who are likely to be materially impacted by the undertaking, including impacts connected with the undertaking’s own operations and value chain, including through its products or services, as well as through its business relationships, are included in the scope of its disclosure under ESRS 2. In addition, the undertaking shall disclose the following information: (a) a brief description of the types of consumers and/or end-users subject to material impacts by its own operations or through its value chain, and specify whether they are: i. consumers and/or end-users of products that are inherently harmful to people and/or increase risks for chronic disease; ii. consumers and/or end-users of services that potentially negatively impact their rights to privacy, to have their personal data protected, to freedom of expression and to non-discrimination; iii. consumers and/or end-users who are dependent on accurate and accessible product- or service-related information, such as manuals and product labels, to avoid potentially damaging use of a product or service; iv. consumers and/or end-users who are particularly vulnerable to health or privacy impacts or impacts from marketing and sales strategies, such as children or financially vulnerable individuals; (b) in the case of material negative impacts, whether they are either (i) widespread or systemic in contexts where the undertaking sells or provides its products or services (for example, state surveillance that affects the privacy of service users), or (ii) related to individual incidents (for example, a defect linked to a particular product) or to specific business relationships (for example, a business partner uses marketing that inappropriately targets young consumers); (c) in the case of material positive impacts, a brief description of the activities that result in the positive impacts (for example, product design that improves its accessibility for persons with disabilities) and the types of consumers and/or end-users that are positively affected or could be positively affected; the undertaking may also disclose whether the positive impacts occur in specific countries or regions; and (d) any material risks and opportunities for the business arising from impacts and dependencies on consumers and/or end-users.

fact-18.value: These risks and opportunities inform our strategy from both a social impact angle (maintaining user privacy and trust) and a financial perspective (reducing potential legal, operational, and reputational costs). By safeguarding user data, we reduce negative social impacts on privacy while also mitigating possible financial liabilities and leveraging brand differentiation.

fact-19.value: We have adopted a Consumer & User Privacy Policy to address these identified risks, ensuring structured processes to mitigate any negative impacts for impacted stakeholders.

concept_group.definition: [401010] S1-1 Policies related to own workforce

parsed_references.text: 17. The undertaking shall describe its policies adopted to manage its material impacts on its own workforce, as well as associated material risks and opportunities.
14. The undertaking shall describe its policies adopted to manage its material impacts on value chain workers, as well as associated material risks and opportunities.
12. The undertaking shall describe its policies adopted to manage its material impacts on affected communities, as well as associated material risks and opportunities.
The undertaking shall describe its policies adopted to manage its material impacts of its products and/or services on consumers and end-users, as well as associated material risks and opportunities.

fact-20.value: To monitor compliance with international frameworks, we conduct annual internal audits referencing the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights, and require third-party data processors to do the same.

concept_group.definition: [401010] S1-1 Policies related to own workforce

parsed_references.text: The undertaking shall describe its human rights policy commitments that are relevant to consumers and/or end-users, including those processes and mechanisms to monitor compliance with the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights, ILO Declaration on Fundamental Principles and Rights at Work or OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises. In its disclosure it shall focus on those matters that are material, as well as the general approach in relation to: (a) respect for the human rights of consumers and/or end-users; (b) engagement with consumers and/or end-users; and (c) measures to provide and/or enable remedy for human rights impacts.

17. The undertaking shall describe its human rights policy commitments that are relevant to value chain workers, including those processes and mechanisms to monitor compliance with the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights, ILO Declaration on Fundamental Principles and Rights at Work or OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises. In its disclosure, it shall focus on those matters that are material in relation to, as well as the general approach to:
(a) respect for the human rights, including labour rights, of workers;
(b) engagement with value chain workers; and
(c) measures to provide and/or enable remedy for human rights impacts.

16. The undertaking shall describe its human rights policy commitments that are relevant to affected communities, including those processes and mechanisms to monitor compliance with the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights, ILO Declaration on Fundamental Principles and Rights at Work or OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises. In its disclosure it shall focus on those matters that are material in relation to, as well as its general approach to:
(a) respect for the human rights of communities, and indigenous peoples specifically;
(b) engagement with affected communities; and
(c) measures to provide and/or enable remedy for human rights impacts.

20. The undertaking shall describe its human rights policy commitments that are relevant to its own workforce, including those processes and mechanisms to monitor compliance with the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights, ILO Declaration on Fundamental Principles and Rights at Work and the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises. In its disclosure it shall focus on those matters that are material in relation to, as well as its general approach to:
(a) respect for the human rights, including labour rights, of people in its own workforce;
(b) engagement with people in its own workforce; and
(c) measures to provide and/or enable remedy for human rights impacts.

fact-21.value: Within this policy, protecting consumer and end-user rights is critical. We focus on data minimization, explicit consent, and transparent usage details that align with recognized international human rights standards.

parsed_references.text: 21. The undertaking shall disclose whether and how its policies with regard to its own workforce are aligned with relevant internationally recognised instruments, including the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights.

The undertaking shall disclose whether and how its policies with regard to consumers and/or end-users are aligned with internationally recognised instruments relevant to consumers and/or end-users, including United Nations (UN) Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights. The undertaking shall also disclose the extent to which cases of non-respect of the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights, ILO Declaration on Fundamental Principles and Rights at Work or OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises that involve consumers and/or end-users have been reported in its downstream value chain and, if applicable, an indication of the nature of such cases.

19. The undertaking shall disclose whether and how its policies with regard to value chain workers are aligned with internationally recognised instruments relevant to value chain workers, including the United Nations (UN) Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights. The undertaking shall also disclose the extent to which cases of non-respect of the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights, ILO Declaration on Fundamental Principles and Rights at Work or OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises that involve value chain workers have been reported in its upstream and downstream value chain and, if applicable, an indication of the nature of such cases.

17. The undertaking shall disclose whether and how its policies with regard to affected communities are aligned with internationally recognised standards relevant to communities and indigenous peoples specifically, including the United Nations (UN) Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights. The undertaking shall also disclose the extent to which cases of non-respect of the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights, ILO Declaration on Fundamental Principles and Rights at Work or OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises that involve affected communities have been reported in its own operations or in its upstream and downstream value chain and, if applicable, an indication of the nature of such cases.

fact-24.value: Our Consumer & User Privacy Policy aligns with GDPR, the OECD Privacy Framework, and the UN Guiding Principles, ensuring consistent global standards in how we manage user data and safeguard their rights.

fact-32.value: This policy addresses the full scope of data usage across R&D, customer support, and marketing to mitigate privacy risks and ensure consistent protections for impacted users throughout our value chain.

fact-33.value: Key contents of our Consumer & User Privacy Policy include explicit data encryption standards, mandatory employee training on privacy, and robust breach notification protocols, all aligned with recognized international frameworks.

concept_group.definition: [201210] ESRS2.MDR-P.1 Minimum Disclosure Requirement - Policies MDR-P - general

fact-34.value: This policy applies enterprise-wide, including all internal teams and primary vendors. We exclude minor outsourced tasks if those suppliers never handle end-user data. Risk-based audits help ensure coverage remains aligned with changing supplier engagements.

concept_group.definition: [201210] ESRS2.MDR-P.1 Minimum Disclosure Requirement - Policies MDR-P - general

fact-35.value: Overall accountability sits with our Chief Privacy Officer, who reports quarterly to the Board’s Sustainability Committee. The Committee includes representatives from Legal, Compliance, R&D, and CSR teams to oversee sustainability impacts, risks, and opportunities. This structure clarifies roles, ensures cross-functional awareness, and strengthens board-level accountability for data privacy and broader ESG matters.

concept_group.definition: [201210] ESRS2.MDR-P.1 Minimum Disclosure Requirement - Policies MDR-P - general

fact-36.value: We reference ISO 27001 and the UN Global Compact in addition to the UNGP for data security and ethical considerations, verifying that our policy is in sync with widely recognized standards.

fact-37.value: When developing this policy, we considered input from key stakeholders, including user advocacy groups and community representatives, ensuring that concerns about data handling and privacy were adequately addressed.

concept_group.definition: [201210] ESRS2.MDR-P.1 Minimum Disclosure Requirement - Policies MDR-P - general

fact-39.value: We publicly post our Consumer & User Privacy Policy on our intranet for employees and on our corporate website for external stakeholders. We also distribute a summary document to any partner organizations handling sensitive data.

fact-40.value: To demonstrate compliance with ESRS disclosure requirements, references to relevant sections of our policy (e.g., breach notification clauses) are included in our annual reporting. Each policy aspect aligns with local and international user-protection mandates.

fact-41.value: We share policy updates via webinars, email bulletins, and online training modules, ensuring employees, suppliers, and user advocacy groups understand its implications. We also remove barriers by offering localized translations where needed.

fact-42.value: We maintain a general engagement process with our consumers and end-users via quarterly feedback surveys and user forums, where participants can discuss both positive and negative impacts they observe.

The undertaking shall disclose its general processes for engaging with consumers and end-users and their representatives about actual and potential impacts on them.

19. The undertaking shall disclose its general processes for engaging with affected communities and their representatives about actual and potential impacts on them.

fact-44.value: By analyzing user complaints and suggestions, we prioritize data-privacy enhancements in our product roadmap, ensuring we address real consumer issues. This feedback loop has led to improved encryption measures and clearer consent forms.

fact-46.value: Engagement starts during initial product design (collecting requirements and concerns), continues at beta testing (validating user feedback), and recurs post-launch at six-month intervals. We typically combine online surveys with virtual user panels.

concept_group.definition: [401020] S1-2 Processes for engaging with own workforce and workers’ representatives about impacts

parsed_references.text: The undertaking shall disclose whether and how the perspectives of consumers and/or end-users inform its decisions or activities aimed at managing actual and potential impacts on consumers and/or end-users. This shall include, where relevant, an explanation of: (a) whether engagement occurs with affected consumers and/or end-users or their legitimate representatives directly, or with credible proxies that have insight into their situation; (b) the stage(s) at which engagement occurs, the type of engagement, and the frequency of the engagement; (c) the function and the most senior role within the undertaking that has operational responsibility for ensuring this engagement happens and that the results inform the undertaking’s approach; and (d) where applicable, how the undertaking assesses the effectiveness of its engagement with consumers and/or end-users, and, where relevant, any agreements or outcomes that result from such engagement.

fact-47.value: Operational responsibility rests with our Head of User Trust & Safety, who ensures user forums are scheduled and that relevant feedback is escalated to the Product Council and Board if needed.

fact-52.value: Currently, we have a Remediation & Resolution Team that collaborates with external mediators when negative impacts on end-users arise, ensuring any complaints are managed promptly and fairly.

fact-53.value: When we determine that we have caused or contributed to a material negative impact, we offer direct remedy through individualized compensation or service upgrades, plus an internal investigation to prevent recurrence.

concept_group.definition: [401030] S1-3 Processes to remediate negative impacts and channels for own workforce to raise concerns

parsed_references.text: The undertaking shall describe: (a) its general approach to and processes for providing or contributing to remedy where it has identified that it has caused or contributed to a material negative impact on consumers and/or end-users, including whether and how the undertaking assesses that the remedy provided is effective; (b) any specific channels it has in place for consumers and/or end-users to raise their concerns or needs directly with the undertaking and have them addressed, including whether these are established by the undertaking itself and/or through participation in third-party mechanisms; (c) the processes through which the undertaking supports or requires the availability of such channels by its business relationships; and (d) how it tracks and monitors issues raised and addressed, and how it ensures the effectiveness of the channels, including through involvement of stakeholders who are the intended users.

concept_group.definition: [401030] S1-3 Processes to remediate negative impacts and channels for own workforce to raise concerns

parsed_references.text: The undertaking shall describe: (a) its general approach to and processes for providing or contributing to remedy where it has identified that it has caused or contributed to a material negative impact on consumers and/or end-users, including whether and how the undertaking assesses that the remedy provided is effective; (b) any specific channels it has in place for consumers and/or end-users to raise their concerns or needs directly with the undertaking and have them addressed, including whether these are established by the undertaking itself and/or through participation in third-party mechanisms; (c) the processes through which the undertaking supports or requires the availability of such channels by its business relationships; and (d) how it tracks and monitors issues raised and addressed, and how it ensures the effectiveness of the channels, including through involvement of stakeholders who are the intended users.

fact-54.value: We gauge remedy effectiveness by surveying affected parties after resolution. If satisfaction is below our benchmark, we re-examine whether the remedy approach or compensation offered was adequate.

concept_group.definition: [401030] S1-3 Processes to remediate negative impacts and channels for own workforce to raise concerns

fact-73.value: Our current plan focuses on mitigating negative impacts (e.g., data misuse) while strengthening resilience to systemic risks such as large-scale cyberattacks or major regulatory shifts. We run annual scenario analyses to test our capacity to sustain operations, protect user data centers under extreme conditions, and maintain continuity. Effectiveness is measured by incident response completion times, user satisfaction metrics, and decreased complaint rates.

parsed_references.text: In relation to material impacts, the undertaking shall describe: (a) actions taken, planned or underway to prevent, mitigate or remediate material negative impacts on consumers and/or end-users; (b) whether and how it has taken action to provide or enable remedy in relation to an actual material impact; (c) any additional actions or initiatives it has in place with the primary purpose of positively contributing to improved social outcomes for consumers and/or end-users; and (d) how it tracks and assesses the effectiveness of these actions and initiatives in delivering intended outcomes for consumers and/or end-users.

parsed_references.text: 39. In relation to paragraph 36, the undertaking shall describe the processes through which it identifies what action is needed and appropriate in response to a particular actual or potential negative impact on its own workforce.

In relation to paragraph 28, the undertaking shall describe: (a) the processes through which it identifies what action is needed and appropriate in response to a particular actual or potential negative impact on consumers and/or end-users; (b) its approaches to taking action in relation to specific material negative impacts on consumers and/or end-users, including any action in relation to its own practices regarding product design, marketing or sales, as well as whether wider industry or collaborative action with other relevant parties will be required; and (c) how it ensures that processes to provide or enable remedy in the event of material negative impacts are available and effective in their implementation and outcomes.

33. In relation to paragraph 30, the undertaking shall describe:
(a) the processes through which it identifies what action is needed and appropriate in response to a particular actual or potential negative impact on value chain workers;
(b) its approach to taking action in relation to specific material negative impacts on value chain workers, including any action in relation to its own purchasing or other internal practices, as well as capacity-building or other forms of engagement with entities in the value chain, or forms of collaborative action with industry peers or other relevant parties; and
(c) how it ensures that processes to provide or enable remedy in the event of material negative impacts are available and effective in their implementation and outcomes.

33. In relation to paragraph 29, the undertaking shall describe:
(a) the processes through which it identifies what action is needed and appropriate in response to a particular actual or potential negative impact on affected communities;
(b) its approach to taking action in relation to specific material negative impacts on communities, including any action in relation to its own practices regarding land acquisition, planning and construction, operation or closure practices, as well as whether wider industry or collaborative action with other relevant parties will be required; and
(c) how it ensures that processes to provide or enable remedy in the event of material negative impacts are available and effective in their implementation and outcomes.

fact-84.value: We prioritize immediate remedies, such as rapid patching of security flaws or direct compensation for impacted consumers. Concurrently, we review internal practices to prevent repeated issues.

fact-114.value: This action covers internal operations (R&D, data centers) and key downstream partners that manage user data. Primary geographies include EU, North America, and Asia.

fact-111.value: Within our upstream operations, we conduct quarterly audits and require mandatory compliance training to ensure suppliers meet our data privacy protocols. We also introduced enterprise-wide encryption standards for employee devices and internal product repositories.

fact-112.value: In our downstream operations, we ensure distributors adopt our encryption protocols and data-handling policies. We conduct semiannual compliance checks to verify that all downstream partners maintain consistent user data protections across each region where our products and services operate.

fact-117.value: During 2025, we allocated €2 million to expand encryption capacity, reducing data complaints by 15% so far. These figures reflect consistent progress from prior-year benchmarks.

69. Where the implementation of an action plan requires significant operational expenditures (Opex) and/or capital expenditures (Capex) the undertaking shall:
(a) describe the type of current and future financial and other resources allocated to the action plan, including if applicable, the relevant terms of sustainable finance instruments, such as green bonds, social bonds and green loans, the environmental or social objectives, and whether the ability to implement the actions or action plan depends on specific preconditions, e.g., granting of financial support or public policy and market developments;
(b) provide the amount of current financial resources and explain how they relate to the most relevant amounts presented in the financial statements; and
(c) provide the amount of future financial resources.

(a) describe the type of current and future financial and other resources allocated to the action plan, including if applicable, the relevant terms of sustainable finance instruments, such as green bonds, social bonds and green loans, the environmental or social objectives, and whether the ability to implement the actions or action plan depends on specific preconditions, e.g., granting of financial support or public policy and market developments;
(b) provide the amount of current financial resources and explain how they relate to the most relevant amounts presented in the financial statements; and

69. Where the implementation of an action plan requires significant operational expenditures (Opex) and/or capital expenditures (Capex) the undertaking shall:
(a) describe the type of current and future financial and other resources allocated to the action plan, including if applicable, the relevant terms of sustainable finance instruments, such as green bonds, social bonds and green loans, the environmental or social objectives, and whether the ability to implement the actions or action plan depends on specific preconditions, e.g., granting of financial support or public policy and market developments;
(b) provide the amount of current financial resources and explain how they relate to the most relevant amounts presented in the financial statements; and
(c) provide the amount of future financial resources.

The information required by paragraph 14 shall include: (a) by reference to GHG emission reduction targets (as required by Disclosure Requirement E1-4), an explanation of how the undertaking’s targets are compatible with the limiting of global warming to 1.5°C in line with the Paris Agreement; (b) by reference to GHG emission reduction targets (as required by Disclosure Requirement E1-4) and the climate change mitigation actions (as required by Disclosure Requirement E1-3), an explanation of the decarbonisation levers identified, and key actions planned, including changes in the undertaking’s product and service portfolio and the adoption of new technologies in its own operations, or the upstream and/or downstream value chain; (c) by reference to the climate change mitigation actions (as required by Disclosure Requirement E1-3), an explanation and quantification of the undertaking’s investments and funding supporting the implementation of its transition plan, with a reference to the key performance indicators of taxonomy-aligned CapEx, and where relevant the CapEx plans, that the undertaking discloses in accordance with Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2021/2178; (d) a qualitative assessment of the potential locked-in GHG emissions from the undertaking’s key assets and products. This shall include an explanation of if and how these emissions may jeopardise the achievement of the undertaking’s GHG emission reduction targets and drive transition risk, and if applicable, an explanation of the undertaking’s plans to manage its GHG-intensive and energy-intensive assets and products; (e) for undertakings with economic activities that are covered by delegated regulations on climate adaptation or mitigation under the Taxonomy Regulation, an explanation of any objective or plans (CapEX, CapEx plans,OpEX) that the undertaking has for aligning its economic activities (revenues, CapEx, OpEx) with the criteria established in Commission Delegated Regulation 2021/2139 (29);(f) if applicable, a disclosure of significant CapEx amounts invested during the reporting period related to coal, oil  and gas-related economic activities; (30)(g) a disclosure on whether or not the undertaking is excluded from the EU Paris-aligned Benchmarks; (31)(h) an explanation of how the transition plan is embedded in and aligned with the undertaking’s overall business strategy and financial planning;(i) whether the transition plan is approved by the administrative, management and supervisory bodies; and (j) an explanation of the undertaking’s progress in implementing the transition plan

(a) describe the type of current and future financial and other resources allocated to the action plan, including if applicable, the relevant terms of sustainable finance instruments, such as green bonds, social bonds and green loans, the environmental or social objectives, and whether the ability to implement the actions or action plan depends on specific preconditions, e.g., granting of financial support or public policy and market developments;
(b) provide the amount of current financial resources and explain how they relate to the most relevant amounts presented in the financial statements; and
(c) provide the amount of future financial resources.

69. Where the implementation of an action plan requires significant operational expenditures (Opex) and/or capital expenditures (Capex) the undertaking shall:
(a) describe the type of current and future financial and other resources allocated to the action plan, including if applicable, the relevant terms of sustainable finance instruments, such as green bonds, social bonds and green loans, the environmental or social objectives, and whether the ability to implement the actions or action plan depends on specific preconditions, e.g., granting of financial support or public policy and market developments;
(b) provide the amount of current financial resources and explain how they relate to the most relevant amounts presented in the financial statements; and
(c) provide the amount of future financial resources.

The information required by paragraph 14 shall include: (a) by reference to GHG emission reduction targets (as required by Disclosure Requirement E1-4), an explanation of how the undertaking’s targets are compatible with the limiting of global warming to 1.5°C in line with the Paris Agreement; (b) by reference to GHG emission reduction targets (as required by Disclosure Requirement E1-4) and the climate change mitigation actions (as required by Disclosure Requirement E1-3), an explanation of the decarbonisation levers identified, and key actions planned, including changes in the undertaking’s product and service portfolio and the adoption of new technologies in its own operations, or the upstream and/or downstream value chain; (c) by reference to the climate change mitigation actions (as required by Disclosure Requirement E1-3), an explanation and quantification of the undertaking’s investments and funding supporting the implementation of its transition plan, with a reference to the key performance indicators of taxonomy-aligned CapEx, and where relevant the CapEx plans, that the undertaking discloses in accordance with Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2021/2178; (d) a qualitative assessment of the potential locked-in GHG emissions from the undertaking’s key assets and products. This shall include an explanation of if and how these emissions may jeopardise the achievement of the undertaking’s GHG emission reduction targets and drive transition risk, and if applicable, an explanation of the undertaking’s plans to manage its GHG-intensive and energy-intensive assets and products; (e) for undertakings with economic activities that are covered by delegated regulations on climate adaptation or mitigation under the Taxonomy Regulation, an explanation of any objective or plans (CapEX, CapEx plans,OpEX) that the undertaking has for aligning its economic activities (revenues, CapEx, OpEx) with the criteria established in Commission Delegated Regulation 2021/2139 (29);(f) if applicable, a disclosure of significant CapEx amounts invested during the reporting period related to coal, oil  and gas-related economic activities; (30)(g) a disclosure on whether or not the undertaking is excluded from the EU Paris-aligned Benchmarks; (31)(h) an explanation of how the transition plan is embedded in and aligned with the undertaking’s overall business strategy and financial planning;(i) whether the transition plan is approved by the administrative, management and supervisory bodies; and (j) an explanation of the undertaking’s progress in implementing the transition plan

fact-122.value: We have set a timebound target to reduce confirmed data incidents by 50% within two years, incorporating forward-looking scenario analyses of stricter data regulations and evolving cyber risks. This ensures our target remains outcome-oriented, comprehensive, and aligned with future conditions.

fact-123.value: Our target-setting process involved cross-functional teams, user feedback sessions, and historical complaint analysis to ensure ambitious yet realistic goals consistent with stakeholder expectations.

concept_group.definition: [401050] S1-5 Targets related to managing material negative impacts, advancing positive impacts, and managing material risks and opportunities

parsed_references.text: The undertaking shall disclose the process for setting the targets, including whether and how the undertaking engaged directly with consumers and/or end-users, their legitimate representatives, or with credible proxies that have insight into their situation in: (a) setting any such targets; (b) tracking the undertaking’s performance against them; and (c) identifying, if any, lessons or improvements as a result of the undertaking’s performance.

42. The undertaking shall disclose the process for setting the targets, including whether and how the undertaking engaged directly with workers in the value chain, their legitimate representatives, or with credible proxies that have insight into their situation in:
(a) setting any such targets;
(b) tracking the undertaking’s performance against them; and
(c) identifying any lessons or improvements as a result of the undertaking’s performance.

The undertaking shall disclose the process for setting the targets, including whether and how the undertaking engaged directly with affected communities, their legitimate representatives, or with credible proxies that have insight into their situation in: (a) setting any such targets; (b) tracking the undertaking’s performance against them; and (c) identifying, any, lessons or improvements as a result of the undertaking’s performance

47. The undertaking shall disclose the process for setting the targets, including whether and how the undertaking engaged directly with its own workforce or workers’ representatives in:
(a) setting any such targets;
(b) tracking the undertaking’s performance against them; and
(c) identifying any lessons or improvements as a result of the undertaking’s performance.

fact-125.value: We collaborated with consumer advocates in defining metrics and thresholds, ensuring that our target’s scope aligns with real-world community concerns.

fact-127.value: We invited user advocacy groups to review quarterly progress reports, shaping how we track data-security improvements against established targets.

fact-129.value: Community feedback from our monthly advisory panel influenced how we refine encryption rollouts and user interface adjustments to meet evolving needs.

fact-130.value: Our target (Target1) focuses on Impact1 (data-privacy risk), tied to Policy1. We plan to reduce data incidents by 30% (absolute measure) between 2025 and 2050, with a baseline year of 2026. This aligns with our broader corporate approach: we incorporate user feedback, apply encryption protocols, and measure progress yearly.
